DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar drifted mostly lower in very thin pre-holiday trading Wednesday, dipping to what traders said was its lowest level against the West German mark since the spring of 1988. Gold prices, meanwhile, declined sharply in the United States and overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $400.80 a troy ounce, down $6 from Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York, quoted a late bid for gold at $400.55 an ounce, off $6.45. Currency dealers said the dollar remained pressured by the continued strength of the West German mark and from expectations that U.S. interest rates will decline further because of weakness in the American economy. The mark has been on the rise for several weeks amid rapid political and economic reforms in Eastern Europe. Many economists predict West Germany's economy will be bolstered as more Eastern European countries, including neighboring East Germany, open their doors to the West. In late New York trading, the dollar closed at 1.6895 West German marks, down from 1.7090 Tuesday. Gabriele Schmitt, a currency trader with the Bank of New York, said that was the weakest close this year and the lowest level since April 1988. Although sentiment toward the dollar remains bullish, dealers said they expect trading to remain very light in the two days before the long New Year's holiday weekend. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell to 142.10 Japanese yen from 142.37 yen Tuesday. It traded at 142.05 yen in London, and at 142.00 yen in New York, up from 141.845 yen Tuesday. The dollar was weaker against the British pound. In London, sterling rose to $1.6255 from $1.6205 late Friday. Later, in New York, it fetched $1.6275, up from $1.6265 Tuesday. Most European financial markets were closed on Monday and Tuesday for the Christmas holiday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5295 Swiss francs, down from 1.54525; 5.7600 French francs, down from 5.8020; 1.15735 Canadian dollars, down from 1.6005; and 1,263.75 Italian lire, down from 1,272.75. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday: 1.6895 West German marks, down from 1.7090; 1.5355 Swiss francs, down from 1.5475; 5.7760 French francs, down from 5.8385; 1.9080 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9330; 1,266.00 Italian lire, down from 1,277.75; 1.1587 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1585. Gold closed in London at a late bid price of $406.25 an ounce, down from $412.25 Friday. It fell in Zurich to $406 an ounce from $413. In Hong Kong, gold closed at $408.49 an ounce, down $5.45 from Tuesday. Silver prices also slipped. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.240 a troy ounce, down from $5.512. Silver fell in London to $5.41 an ounce from $5.58 bid Friday.
